cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What is a reality TV show in which a group of people live in a large house watched by cameras, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The question describes a reality TV show format where a group of individuals lives together in a house while being filmed continuously. This concept is widely recognized as a "Big Brother" format. The show originated in the Netherlands and first aired in 1999, which aligns with the details provided in the question. The name "Big Brother" is derived from George Orwell's novel "1984," where the character represents an omnipresent authority figure. 

Answer: Big Brother

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
What is a reality TV show in which a group of people live in a large house watched by cameras, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Real World: Stockholm was the first reality television show to be broadcast on Swedish television. Based on the successful American TV show "The Real World", the show premiered on 1 October 1995 on TV1000. Following the show\'s success, "" aired in 1996, but it became the last Real World season in Sweden following poor ratings.\n', '"The Real World" is an American reality television show in which a group of strangers live together in a house for several months, as cameras record their interpersonal relationships. First broadcast in 1992, the show is the longest-running program in MTV history, consistently ranking as a top-rated cable series among viewers 12–34 years old. 30 seasons have aired in their entirety.\n', 'Reality TV was a popular genre of television programming in the UK in 2002. The third series of the UK version of "Big Brother"—which was showing while Russian\'s con took place—attracted audience figures of approximately 5.8\xa0million. Most British reality TV programmes at the time centred on a team of people trying to accomplish a specific goal or target. For example, the 2000 series "Jailbreak" challenged a group to escape from a mock prison, while the 2001 series "The Mole" gave the contestants the task of discovering which of them was sabotaging their attempts to win money. Most reality TV shows offered a cash reward to successful participants—both "Jailbreak" and the first series of "The Mole" offered a prize of £100,000.\n', 'The series "Expedition Robinson", created by television producer Charlie Parsons, which first aired in 1997 in Sweden (and was later produced in a large number of other countries as "Survivor"), added to the "Nummer 28"/"Real World" template the idea of competition and elimination. Cast members/contestants battled against each other and were removed from the show until only one winner remained (these shows are now sometimes called elimination shows). "Changing Rooms", a program that began in 1996, showed couples redecorating each other\'s houses, and was the first reality show with a self-improvement or makeover theme. The dating reality show "Streetmate" premiered in the UK in 1998. Originally created by Gabe Sachs as "Street Match", it was a flop in the United States. But the show was revamped in the UK by Tiger Aspect Productions and became a cult hit. The production team from the original series later created the popular reality shows "Strictly Come Dancing", "Location, Location, Location", and the revamped "MasterChef", among others. The 1980s and 1990s were also a time when tabloid talk shows became more popular. Many of these featured the same types of unusual or dysfunctional guests who would later become popular as cast members of reality shows.\n', 'The Való Világ (Real World) is Hungary\'s reality show aired by RTL Klub. ValóVilág became the most popular Hungarian reality television programme ever. The show was aired in the same time slot as the localized version of "Big Brother". While TV2 recorded the highest number of viewers in 2002, VV1 had an average 1.5 million. In 2003, VV2 was a breakthrough. While it had 1.75 million viewers daily, BB2 recorded only 800 000 viewers. RTL Klub started the third season, which was an absolute success with 2.06 million viewers daily. The first three seasons were broadcast between 2002 and 2004, but returned in November 2010 for the fourth season after years of hiatus.\n', 'Open Het Dorp ("Open The Village") was the first big fundraising TV show in the Netherlands. It aired on Dutch TV on 26 and 27 November 1962.\n', 'In 2004, POP TV introduced their first reality show. "Sanjski moški" (2004) was the Slovenian version of "The Bachelor", and lasted for one season. In the same year, "Naša mala klinika" (2004-2007), a new Slovenian sitcom, was introduced and lasted for seven full seasons. The sitcom was watched on average by 300.000 people against 2 million people, which is the population of Slovenia. In the next year, two new reality shows were introduced: "Sanjska ženska" (2005-2006), a local version of "The Bachelorette" which lasted for two seasons, and a Slovenian version of reality show "The Bar", called "Bar" (2005-2006), which lasted also for two seasons. A hidden-camera show called "Oprostite, prosim!", "Vzemi ali pusti" (2005-2008), local version of "Deal or No Deal" and music show "Raketa pod kozolcem" (2005-2006), also premiered in 2005. POP TV also co-produced a new crime series named "Balkan Inc." (2006), with Nova TV and TV Pink.\n', 'The first breakthrough came in 2002 with their hidden camera-program "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" ("Pardon the mess (we\'re redecorating)") broadcast by TV4. The program created viewer storms, debates and was reported to Swedish Broadcasting Commission several times. Six episodes were made but only four aired. The concept involved Filip and Fredrik making fun of both famous and unknown people using a hidden camera and similar setups. The show was largely influenced by shows like "Pyjamas", a similar show that aired the year before on youth channel ZTV. The jokes were of a rather unusual, sometimes experimental, nature and some viewers took offense, feeling that the pair were humiliating innocent people. Often the "jokes" were taken far beyond what in most people produced a laugh. The show made headlines due to a segment called "the Swedish Nazi-reference championship" where they fooled singer and former Expedition Robinson-star Emma Andersson into an interview where they made as many Nazi-references as possible and observed her reactions. Due to that segment, TV4 was fined by the Swedish Broadcasting Commission who argued that, since Emma was not a political person, the segment was intrusive to her privacy and integrity. Fredrik has later said that "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" was an order from TV4 because they wanted a show that 90% hated and 10% liked.\n', 'Precedents for television that portrayed people in unscripted situations began in the late 1940s. "Queen for a Day" (1945–1964) was an early example of reality-based television. The 1946 television game show "Cash and Carry" sometimes featured contestants performing stunts. Debuting in 1948, Allen Funt\'s hidden camera show, "Candid Camera" (based on his previous 1947 radio show, "Candid Microphone"), broadcast unsuspecting ordinary people reacting to pranks. In 1948, talent search shows, such as "Ted Mack\'s Original Amateur Hour" and "Arthur Godfrey\'s Talent Scouts", featured amateur competitors and audience voting. In the 1950s, game shows "Beat the Clock" and "Truth or Consequences" involved contestants in wacky competitions, stunts, and practical jokes. "Confession" was a crime/police show that aired from June 1958 to January 1959, with interviewer Jack Wyatt questioning criminals from assorted backgrounds. The radio series "Nightwatch" (1951–1955) tape-recorded the daily activities of Culver City, California police officers. The series "You Asked for It" (1950–1959) incorporated audience involvement by basing episodes around requests sent in by postcard from viewers. "You\'re Another", a science fiction short story by American writer Damon Knight, was first published in the June 1955 issue of "The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction". It has perhaps the earliest fictional depiction of what is now called reality television.\n', 'The Real World: Visby was a Swedish and Norwegian reality television program that was broadcast on TV1000 in late 1996. The show was a Swedish version of the hit American reality show "The Real World" that is still produced in America. It was Sweden\'s second season of the show since the first season "" was highly successful. However, The Real World: Visby became the last Real World season in Sweden, since the ratings dropped to an all-time low. \n']

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The question asks for a reality TV show that features a group of people living together in a large house under constant surveillance, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999. This description closely aligns with the format of "Big Brother," which is a well-known reality TV concept that originated in the Netherlands.

1. **Understanding Reality TV Formats**:
   - The concept of reality TV where individuals live together in a house and are filmed continuously is a hallmark of the "Big Brother" format. This format emphasizes social dynamics, interpersonal relationships, and the impact of constant observation on behavior.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - "Big Brother" first aired in the Netherlands in 1999, making it the first show of its kind in that country. This aligns perfectly with the details in the question. The show has since been adapted in numerous countries, becoming a global phenomenon.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The name "Big Brother" is derived from George Orwell's dystopian novel "1984," where it symbolizes an omnipresent authority that monitors individuals. This cultural reference adds depth to the understanding of the show's themes, such as surveillance, privacy, and social behavior.

4. **Influence of Predecessors**:
   - While "The Real World" (1992) set the stage for reality TV by showcasing group dynamics in a shared living space, "Big Brother" took this concept further by introducing the element of competition and public voting, which became central to its format.

5. **Global Adaptation**:
   - The success of "Big Brother" in the Netherlands led to its adaptation in various countries, each with localized versions that reflect cultural nuances. This highlights the show's flexibility and appeal across different audiences.

### Answer:
Based on the enhanced reasoning process, the reality TV show in which a group of people live in a large house watched by cameras, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999, is **Big Brother**.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on Reality TV Shows**

**Expert 1: The Historical Context Expert**
"I'd like to start by emphasizing the historical context of reality television. The genre has roots that trace back to the late 1940s with shows like 'Queen for a Day' and 'Candid Camera.' These early programs laid the groundwork for unscripted television, which has evolved significantly over the decades. The passage mentions that 'The Real World,' which began in 1992, is a pivotal show in this evolution. However, the question specifically asks about a show first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999, which points to 'Big Brother' as the likely candidate."

**Expert 2: The Format and Genre Expert**
"I agree with the historical perspective, but I want to focus on the format of reality TV. The concept of a group of people living together in a house, monitored by cameras, is a hallmark of the 'Big Brother' format. This show, which originated in the Netherlands, introduced a competitive element to the reality genre, influencing numerous adaptations worldwide. The passages highlight how 'Expedition Robinson' (the Swedish version of 'Survivor') also added competition to the mix, but 'Big Brother' is distinct in its social experiment approach without physical challenges."

**Expert 3: The Cultural Impact Expert**
"Both of you make valid points. However, I would like to discuss the cultural impact of these shows. 'Big Brother' not only popularized the reality TV format in the Netherlands but also sparked a global phenomenon. The passage about the UK version of 'Big Brother' attracting millions of viewers illustrates its significant cultural footprint. This show has influenced public perceptions of privacy and celebrity, as it thrust ordinary individuals into the spotlight, often leading to fame and notoriety."

**Expert 4: The Evolution of Reality TV Expert**
"I appreciate the insights on cultural impact and format. However, I think it’s essential to consider how reality TV has evolved since its inception. The passage mentions various reality shows that emerged in the late 1990s and early 2000s, indicating a diversification of the genre. While 'Big Brother' is a foundational show, the introduction of competition in shows like 'Survivor' and the makeover theme in 'Changing Rooms' reflects a shift towards more structured formats that appeal to different audiences."

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement**
- **Agreement**: All experts agree that 'Big Brother' is a significant reality TV show that originated in the Netherlands and fits the description of a group living in a monitored environment.
- **Disagreement**: The experts diverge on the emphasis of their perspectives; some focus on the historical context, while others highlight the cultural impact or the evolution of the genre.

**Synthesis of Insights**
The discussion reveals a multifaceted understanding of reality television, particularly the show that first aired in the Netherlands in 1999. 'Big Brother' is recognized as a pioneering format that combines social experimentation with entertainment, influencing both the genre and societal views on privacy and fame. The evolution of reality TV has led to a diversification of formats, showcasing how the genre has adapted to audience preferences over time. This collaborative dialogue underscores the importance of considering various perspectives to fully appreciate the complexities of reality television's impact on culture and media. 

In conclusion, while 'Big Brother' stands out as a landmark show, its legacy is intertwined with the broader evolution of reality TV, reflecting changing societal norms and entertainment values.

This context is crucial as it situates 'Big Brother' within a broader narrative of television history, illustrating how the genre has developed over time.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
What is a reality TV show in which a group of people live in a large house watched by cameras, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Real World: Stockholm was the first reality television show to be broadcast on Swedish television. Based on the successful American TV show "The Real World", the show premiered on 1 October 1995 on TV1000. Following the show's success, "" aired in 1996, but it became the last Real World season in Sweden following poor ratings.
', '"The Real World" is an American reality television show in which a group of strangers live together in a house for several months, as cameras record their interpersonal relationships. First broadcast in 1992, the show is the longest-running program in MTV history, consistently ranking as a top-rated cable series among viewers 12–34 years old. 30 seasons have aired in their entirety.
', 'Reality TV was a popular genre of television programming in the UK in 2002. The third series of the UK version of "Big Brother"—which was showing while Russian's con took place—attracted audience figures of approximately 5.8\xa0million. Most British reality TV programmes at the time centred on a team of people trying to accomplish a specific goal or target. For example, the 2000 series "Jailbreak" challenged a group to escape from a mock prison, while the 2001 series "The Mole" gave the contestants the task of discovering which of them was sabotaging their attempts to win money. Most reality TV shows offered a cash reward to successful participants—both "Jailbreak" and the first series of "The Mole" offered a prize of £100,000.
', 'The series "Expedition Robinson", created by television producer Charlie Parsons, which first aired in 1997 in Sweden (and was later produced in a large number of other countries as "Survivor"), added to the "Nummer 28"/"Real World" template the idea of competition and elimination. Cast members/contestants battled against each other and were removed from the show until only one winner remained (these shows are now sometimes called elimination shows). "Changing Rooms", a program that began in 1996, showed couples redecorating each other's houses, and was the first reality show with a self-improvement or makeover theme. The dating reality show "Streetmate" premiered in the UK in 1998. Originally created by Gabe Sachs as "Street Match", it was a flop in the United States. But the show was revamped in the UK by Tiger Aspect Productions and became a cult hit. The production team from the original series later created the popular reality shows "Strictly Come Dancing", "Location, Location, Location", and the revamped "MasterChef", among others. The 1980s and 1990s were also a time when tabloid talk shows became more popular. Many of these featured the same types of unusual or dysfunctional guests who would later become popular as cast members of reality shows.
', 'The Való Világ (Real World) is Hungary's reality show aired by RTL Klub. ValóVilág became the most popular Hungarian reality television programme ever. The show was aired in the same time slot as the localized version of "Big Brother". While TV2 recorded the highest number of viewers in 2002, VV1 had an average 1.5 million. In 2003, VV2 was a breakthrough. While it had 1.75 million viewers daily, BB2 recorded only 800 000 viewers. RTL Klub started the third season, which was an absolute success with 2.06 million viewers daily. The first three seasons were broadcast between 2002 and 2004, but returned in November 2010 for the fourth season after years of hiatus.
', 'Open Het Dorp ("Open The Village") was the first big fundraising TV show in the Netherlands. It aired on Dutch TV on 26 and 27 November 1962.
', 'In 2004, POP TV introduced their first reality show. "Sanjski moški" (2004) was the Slovenian version of "The Bachelor", and lasted for one season. In the same year, "Naša mala klinika" (2004-2007), a new Slovenian sitcom, was introduced and lasted for seven full seasons. The sitcom was watched on average by 300.000 people against 2 million people, which is the population of Slovenia. In the next year, two new reality shows were introduced: "Sanjska ženska" (2005-2006), a local version of "The Bachelorette" which lasted for two seasons, and a Slovenian version of reality show "The Bar", called "Bar" (2005-2006), which lasted also for two seasons. A hidden-camera show called "Oprostite, prosim!", "Vzemi ali pusti" (2005-2008), local version of "Deal or No Deal" and music show "Raketa pod kozolcem" (2005-2006), also premiered in 2005. POP TV also co-produced a new crime series named "Balkan Inc." (2006), with Nova TV and TV Pink.
', 'The first breakthrough came in 2002 with their hidden camera-program "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" ("Pardon the mess (we're redecorating)") broadcast by TV4. The program created viewer storms, debates and was reported to Swedish Broadcasting Commission several times. Six episodes were made but only four aired. The concept involved Filip and Fredrik making fun of both famous and unknown people using a hidden camera and similar setups. The show was largely influenced by shows like "Pyjamas", a similar show that aired the year before on youth channel ZTV. The jokes were of a rather unusual, sometimes experimental, nature and some viewers took offense, feeling that the pair were humiliating innocent people. Often the "jokes" were taken far beyond what in most people produced a laugh. The show made headlines due to a segment called "the Swedish Nazi-reference championship" where they fooled singer and former Expedition Robinson-star Emma Andersson into an interview where they made as many Nazi-references as possible and observed her reactions. Due to that segment, TV4 was fined by the Swedish Broadcasting Commission who argued that, since Emma was not a political person, the segment was intrusive to her privacy and integrity. Fredrik has later said that "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" was an order from TV4 because they wanted a show that 90% hated and 10% liked.
', 'Precedents for television that portrayed people in unscripted situations began in the late 1940s. "Queen for a Day" (1945–1964) was an early example of reality-based television. The 1946 television game show "Cash and Carry" sometimes featured contestants performing stunts. Debuting in 1948, Allen Funt's hidden camera show, "Candid Camera" (based on his previous 1947 radio show, "Candid Microphone"), broadcast unsuspecting ordinary people reacting to pranks. In 1948, talent search shows, such as "Ted Mack's Original Amateur Hour" and "Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts", featured amateur competitors and audience voting. In the 1950s, game shows "Beat the Clock" and "Truth or Consequences" involved contestants in wacky competitions, stunts, and practical jokes. "Confession" was a crime/police show that aired from June 1958 to January 1959, with interviewer Jack Wyatt questioning criminals from assorted backgrounds. The radio series "Nightwatch" (1951–1955) tape-recorded the daily activities of Culver City, California police officers. The series "You Asked for It" (1950–1959) incorporated audience involvement by basing episodes around requests sent in by postcard from viewers. "You're Another", a science fiction short story by American writer Damon Knight, was first published in the June 1955 issue of "The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction". It has perhaps the earliest fictional depiction of what is now called reality television.
', 'The Real World: Visby was a Swedish and Norwegian reality television program that was broadcast on TV1000 in late 1996. The show was a Swedish version of the hit American reality show "The Real World" that is still produced in America. It was Sweden's second season of the show since the first season "" was highly successful. However, The Real World: Visby became the last Real World season in Sweden, since the ratings dropped to an all-time low. 
']

The question asks for a specific reality TV show format where a group of people lives in a large house under constant surveillance, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999. This description aligns closely with the "Big Brother" format, which is characterized by the following elements:

The format typically includes various challenges and social dynamics among the contestants, leading to eliminations and a final winner.

2. **Origin and Impact**: The show first aired in the Netherlands in 1999, created by John de Mol. Its success in the Netherlands led to numerous adaptations in various countries, making it a significant cultural phenomenon in reality television history.

3. **Cultural Significance**: The name "Big Brother" is derived from George Orwell's dystopian novel "1984," symbolizing surveillance and control. This connection adds a layer of social commentary to the show, as it explores themes of privacy, human behavior, and societal norms.

4. **Global Influence**: The format's popularity has resulted in multiple international versions, demonstrating how a successful concept can transcend cultural boundaries and adapt to different audiences. By synthesizing the information about "Big Brother," its origins, and its cultural significance, we can enhance the model's reasoning capabilities. This includes recognizing the implications of surveillance in media, understanding the dynamics of reality TV, and identifying patterns in cultural adaptations.

Big Brother

**Answer**: Big Brother

question_info.question: What is a reality TV show in which a group of people live in a large house watched by cameras, first broadcast in the Netherlands in 1999?
passages:
The Real World: Stockholm was the first reality television show to be broadcast on Swedish television. Based on the successful American TV show "The Real World", the show premiered on 1 October 1995 on TV1000. Following the show's success, "" aired in 1996, but it became the last Real World season in Sweden following poor ratings.
"The Real World" is an American reality television show in which a group of strangers live together in a house for several months, as cameras record their interpersonal relationships. First broadcast in 1992, the show is the longest-running program in MTV history, consistently ranking as a top-rated cable series among viewers 12–34 years old. 30 seasons have aired in their entirety.
Reality TV was a popular genre of television programming in the UK in 2002. The third series of the UK version of "Big Brother"—which was showing while Russian's con took place—attracted audience figures of approximately 5.8 million. Most British reality TV programmes at the time centred on a team of people trying to accomplish a specific goal or target. For example, the 2000 series "Jailbreak" challenged a group to escape from a mock prison, while the 2001 series "The Mole" gave the contestants the task of discovering which of them was sabotaging their attempts to win money. Most reality TV shows offered a cash reward to successful participants—both "Jailbreak" and the first series of "The Mole" offered a prize of £100,000.
The series "Expedition Robinson", created by television producer Charlie Parsons, which first aired in 1997 in Sweden (and was later produced in a large number of other countries as "Survivor"), added to the "Nummer 28"/"Real World" template the idea of competition and elimination. Cast members/contestants battled against each other and were removed from the show until only one winner remained (these shows are now sometimes called elimination shows). "Changing Rooms", a program that began in 1996, showed couples redecorating each other's houses, and was the first reality show with a self-improvement or makeover theme. The dating reality show "Streetmate" premiered in the UK in 1998. Originally created by Gabe Sachs as "Street Match", it was a flop in the United States. But the show was revamped in the UK by Tiger Aspect Productions and became a cult hit. The production team from the original series later created the popular reality shows "Strictly Come Dancing", "Location, Location, Location", and the revamped "MasterChef", among others. The 1980s and 1990s were also a time when tabloid talk shows became more popular. Many of these featured the same types of unusual or dysfunctional guests who would later become popular as cast members of reality shows.
The Való Világ (Real World) is Hungary's reality show aired by RTL Klub. ValóVilág became the most popular Hungarian reality television programme ever. The show was aired in the same time slot as the localized version of "Big Brother". While TV2 recorded the highest number of viewers in 2002, VV1 had an average 1.5 million. In 2003, VV2 was a breakthrough. While it had 1.75 million viewers daily, BB2 recorded only 800 000 viewers. RTL Klub started the third season, which was an absolute success with 2.06 million viewers daily. The first three seasons were broadcast between 2002 and 2004, but returned in November 2010 for the fourth season after years of hiatus.
Open Het Dorp ("Open The Village") was the first big fundraising TV show in the Netherlands. It aired on Dutch TV on 26 and 27 November 1962.
In 2004, POP TV introduced their first reality show. "Sanjski moški" (2004) was the Slovenian version of "The Bachelor", and lasted for one season. In the same year, "Naša mala klinika" (2004-2007), a new Slovenian sitcom, was introduced and lasted for seven full seasons. The sitcom was watched on average by 300.000 people against 2 million people, which is the population of Slovenia. In the next year, two new reality shows were introduced: "Sanjska ženska" (2005-2006), a local version of "The Bachelorette" which lasted for two seasons, and a Slovenian version of reality show "The Bar", called "Bar" (2005-2006), which lasted also for two seasons. A hidden-camera show called "Oprostite, prosim!", "Vzemi ali pusti" (2005-2008), local version of "Deal or No Deal" and music show "Raketa pod kozolcem" (2005-2006), also premiered in 2005. POP TV also co-produced a new crime series named "Balkan Inc." (2006), with Nova TV and TV Pink.
The first breakthrough came in 2002 with their hidden camera-program "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" ("Pardon the mess (we're redecorating)") broadcast by TV4. The program created viewer storms, debates and was reported to Swedish Broadcasting Commission several times. Six episodes were made but only four aired. The concept involved Filip and Fredrik making fun of both famous and unknown people using a hidden camera and similar setups. The show was largely influenced by shows like "Pyjamas", a similar show that aired the year before on youth channel ZTV. The jokes were of a rather unusual, sometimes experimental, nature and some viewers took offense, feeling that the pair were humiliating innocent people. Often the "jokes" were taken far beyond what in most people produced a laugh. The show made headlines due to a segment called "the Swedish Nazi-reference championship" where they fooled singer and former Expedition Robinson-star Emma Andersson into an interview where they made as many Nazi-references as possible and observed her reactions. Due to that segment, TV4 was fined by the Swedish Broadcasting Commission who argued that, since Emma was not a political person, the segment was intrusive to her privacy and integrity. Fredrik has later said that "Ursäkta röran (vi bygger om)" was an order from TV4 because they wanted a show that 90% hated and 10% liked.
Precedents for television that portrayed people in unscripted situations began in the late 1940s. "Queen for a Day" (1945–1964) was an early example of reality-based television. The 1946 television game show "Cash and Carry" sometimes featured contestants performing stunts. Debuting in 1948, Allen Funt's hidden camera show, "Candid Camera" (based on his previous 1947 radio show, "Candid Microphone"), broadcast unsuspecting ordinary people reacting to pranks. In 1948, talent search shows, such as "Ted Mack's Original Amateur Hour" and "Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts", featured amateur competitors and audience voting. In the 1950s, game shows "Beat the Clock" and "Truth or Consequences" involved contestants in wacky competitions, stunts, and practical jokes. "Confession" was a crime/police show that aired from June 1958 to January 1959, with interviewer Jack Wyatt questioning criminals from assorted backgrounds. The radio series "Nightwatch" (1951–1955) tape-recorded the daily activities of Culver City, California police officers. The series "You Asked for It" (1950–1959) incorporated audience involvement by basing episodes around requests sent in by postcard from viewers. "You're Another", a science fiction short story by American writer Damon Knight, was first published in the June 1955 issue of "The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction". It has perhaps the earliest fictional depiction of what is now called reality television.
The Real World: Visby was a Swedish and Norwegian reality television program that was broadcast on TV1000 in late 1996. The show was a Swedish version of the hit American reality show "The Real World" that is still produced in America. It was Sweden's second season of the show since the first season "" was highly successful. However, The Real World: Visby became the last Real World season in Sweden, since the ratings dropped to an all-time low.
